Killing Floor is a very good Action Survival FPS. It has many classes and guns to choose from and the leveling system is great, There are guns in the game you can buy for real money, but these are just cosmetics they are always just direct copies of free guns in their stats.(exept for a few weapon packs that aren't that great they just add some more fun) There are I think 2 or 3 guns that are a bit better but one is a promotional off of Tripwire Interactives game Rising Storm for Red Orchistra 2. The thing is like 5$ and 1$ on sale so just pick up the tripwire complete pack on sale you get 4 or 5 great games and every DLC for them and it's probably the best deal on Steam aside from the Valve Complete pack. Back to the game play this game has so many different play styles that its pretty hard to get bored off. The only times that I ever get bored are when I am not doing very well. I would highly reccomend this game to anyone who likes left4dead or any zombie survival shooters. Although keep in mind this game is nothing like DayZ. This game has many different zombies some very large maps and many different zombie types. If I were to compare this game to any game it would be Left 4 Dead(both 1 and 2). The reason being this game has a many different types of zombies(crawlers, Flesh Pounds, Skrakes, ect) and left 4 dead has many different zombie types to there are the regular zombies and the tanks and charges and many more. Also after you progress enough you get to a safe house in L4D and in KF you get to buy moer weapons with money you earned from killing zombies. So in a way it is a little bit like COD zombies(I think it is better than COD zombies) and it is alot like L4D. Overall I would give this game 9 zombies out of 10. The reason it is not a complete 10/10 is because it isnt the easiest game to just pick up and be really good at it. It takes a good ammount of time before you can lead your team in a PUG.

Co-Operative round based of killing zombies. They come for you and you kill them. There are a variety that try to kill you.

It is class based and you gain levels in those respective classes to unlock abilities, but your never actually restricted by the weapons you chose.

You also gain money for each kill to buy better weapons, this money is exclusive to the map/game your playing on but have no fear... your ussually able to buy the most expensive weapon mid map anyway.

The difficulty stacks up with the chosen difficulty and the number of players, so more players=harder

Overall, great game if you have to kill 5 minutes or 30. You will almost never find anyone whining and the rpg elements will keep you hooked


Plus there's something about british voices killing zombies that just sounds awesome

Суть такова, у тебя есть анриловский движок и веселые танцы с бубном при подключении, причем танцуют все твои братюни. И если танец выполнен успешно, то есть возможность лишний раз перезарядиться, когда будешь отстреливать набегающих на тебя лалок. Кстати лалки имеют свойство менять свой облик на различные праздники. Но что никогда не меняется, так это твоя перезарядка, ты можешь покупать новое оружие, заваривать двери, лечить, получать новые уровни, но при этом ты всегда будешь перезаряжаться. В эту игру стоит поиграть, как минимум из-за того, чтобы посмотреть как перезаряжаешь. Если не увидел, то посмотри как перезаряжается твой напарник. И только успевая вовремя перезаряжаться, можно выстоять всю игру не умерев. Так что вперед мальчики, за покупками, а то магазин закрывается.
A must for anyone into the zombie/co-op survival genre

Killing Floor is an intense RPG/FPS that can take minutes to get into but hundreds of hours to become proficient at.  The game offers 5 difficulties, the lower of which you can be comfortable playing alone but the higher difficulties demand exceptional teamwork in order to overcome the grisly odds.  Seven different perks that grow in power as you level them up to six times allow you to choose the type of destruction you wish to bring to the mutant freaks.

The combat includes anywhere from one to six players and the more people you have on your squad the larger the force and the bigger the healthpool of the opposition.  The menace you attempt to best with your buddies is as diverse as they are deadly.  Wave-based gameplay gradually introduces you to the specimens while giving you time to save up your dosh for spending at the games rather formidable armory.  

While the game is four years old the developers still release brand new content for the game on a semi-regular basis, with seasonal updates that reskin the specimens you fight into hilariously creepy incarnations.  New characters, new weapons and new maps await even the veteran players every few months.

And last but not least the zambies, with a large variety, you will not be bored- trust me ;D

From an Unreal Tournament 2004 mod comes the definitive standalone horde mode experience.

With tons of levels, monsters, and weapons, this is the place to go to quench your Horde Mode urges.

-------------
Gameplay
-------------
You're placed in a group of 6 players, also known as survivors, trying to survive an onslaught of Zeds, which are the enemies of the game.
Every map is split into waves, depending on the difficulty, the amount of waves is going to vary, as well as the amount of Zeds coming at you.

You're all given the option of 7 different classes: Field Medic, Support Specialist, Sharpshooter, Commando, Berserker, Firebug, and Demolition. All with varying traits, all complimenting each other in one way or another.
At lower difficulties, the make-up of your team doesn't matter much, however, at Hard+ difficulties, it becomes paramount to your success.
Part of this system is also tiers of classes.
Every class gets reduced prices on weapons, specifically made for their class. For example, Firebugs get a reduced price at the trader on Flamethrowers.

While this is overall, very beneficial, it also gives another reason to level your classes. Thankfully, the developers thought this through, and made class progression easy by allowing cross-progression, which essentially means you can progress one class, while playing another. Getting to the elusive Tier 6 will prove time-consuming, but enjoyable none-the-less.

Naturally, this isn't a reliable way of getting better equipment, though it may save your life down the line (it is also a pretty good idea to seek them out at the start of the game for a headstart).
Some weapons are obviously for certain classes, but are still open for use by anyone, no matter the class.

-------------
Maps/Levels
-------------
Level design is also very nice, ranging from abandoned streets, to twisted Santa's workshop.
The size of the levels range wildly between narrow corridor to wide open-air shooting.
Every level features a trader, which you must get to in-between waves. This is where you stock up on ammo, purchase weaponry and armor, and sell unnecessary equipment. Though do offer the weapons to others before doing so.
Of course, if you don't have the money to buy weapons or ammo, then these can also be found around the maps in random locations.

-------------
Controls
-------------
Movement is nice and fluid, with a slight hint of Counter-Strike with the "run faster with your knife out, despite still carrying the same equipment" logic.
The weapon controls are extremely varying, with crossbows, assault rifles, katanas, the before mentioned flamethrowers, and many many more.

-------------
Visuals
-------------
It is very clear that this game originates from a mod based on a game from 2004.
Enemies have decent animations, though with the occasional pathfinding problems.
Some maps outright have enemies floating in mid-air, trying to jump down to you only to find themselves hindered by an invisible wall. Thankfully, this is nothing more than visual annoyances that won't put you out of the action, but still make you go "Huh, that wasn't supposed to happen.".
Texture quality is fine, considering the game's origin.
The slow motion effect that sometimes happens, is something you'll either enjoy or hate. While one class has an ability that extends this effect everytime the person kills something, this can become either tedious very quickly, or a very awesome bullet-time scene for you.

-------------
Audio
-------------
The audio quality is very good.
Guns sound like they'd make the sounds they make, explosions sound... Explosive? And the monsters sound like... Well... Monsters. Especially the Sirens, my god, I hate those things.

-------------
DLC
-------------
This game has tons of DLC, mostly cosmetics, and some weapons.
Now, before you go "Pfft! Those weapons are probably pay 2 win, no thanks!", listen!
The weapons may be stronger, but that comes at a price. The weapon will most of the time be more expensive to obtain, and usually, the standard weapons will be plenty for anyone to use, and succeed with.


-------------
Final Verdict
-------------
In summary, this game is for anyone who enjoys horde modes, if just a little.
If you don't like horde modes, if this won't get you into this type of game, then nothing will!

I whole-heartedly recommend this game to everyone.

-------------
Feedback
-------------
If anything is incorrect, or if I missed anything, please don't hesitate with posting a comment on my profile telling me.

If Team Fortress 2 is light-hearted, brightly coloured, fast paced PvP perfection with beautiful (hilariously ridiculous?) bells (hats?) on then Killing Floor is the flipside of it's FPS coin.
In my view these are THE two shooters every PC gamer should have in their collection.
Up there with Left 4 Dead 2 as THE definitive multi-player zombie shooter, Killing Floor adds persistent character leveling and is the perfect "survival" alternative to L4D2's excellent "journey" based gameplay approach.
If you're looking for a serious, grown-up, spine tingling, and ultimately superb co-op zombie survival shooter then this is most certainly your game.

75%

If you love the survival horror genre, I would absolutely suggest picking this one up. Basically, the premise here is that these "Zeds" (the zombie-like creatures within the game) are failed military experiments wreaking havoc across the UK. Players are assigned with the task of eliminating these creatures under the role of special agents dropped into these Zed hot spots. 

The typical game progresses in waves of Zeds, each wave ending with a trip to a weapons trader who will move from safehouse to safehouse during the progression of each round in order to keep the Zeds on the run. Players choose from one of seven different classes (or Perks, as they're referred to in the game), each including weapon specialization "perks" for picking the class, which include Medic (armor/speed/healing), Sharpshooter (handguns/sniper rifles), Firebug (flamethrower/fire resist), Demolitions Expert (basically anything that explodes), Support (shotguns/welding), Commando (grenades/stealth sight/assault rifles), and Berserker (melee weapon-using close quarters combat specialist). However, your class does not restrict which weapons you can use within the game. It simply gives a boost to your ability with the weapons which fall under that Perk's specialty. Also, each Perk is improved through a leveling EXP system. 

The cool thing about this is that you can level any Perk at any time, depending on your current weapon. EX: Hacking Zeds with a melee weapon will increase your Berserker EXP, shooting off heads in the distance will warrant Sharpshooter EXP, lobbing a grenade into a group will award Commando EXP, and healing a fellow teammate will increase Medic EXP. All in all, this game is great for online and solo play.

Still a damn fun multiplayer Zombie-Shooting good time.  It takes a long time to grind your classes up to higher levels to be useful in high difficulty situations, but there's plenty of fun to be had at the normal difficulty in the meantime.  It's a lot of fun, a good game for parties of friends.

Some enemies do feel a bit bullet spongy but still, that just means teamwork is required.

DO NOT buy this game if you only intend to play alone.  Think of this game as Left4Dead's survival mode, but better, and winnable.

Affronter en solo ou en coop des hordes d'ennemis.
Modes de jeux : vagues classiques, ou objectifs (seulement certaines cartes).
LE + : plusieurs classes differentes qui s'upgrade en jouant leur particularité.

This Zombie Survival game is pretty awesome.  It is pretty much non-stop action, and the selectable classes with their stat differences and leveling is a nice change over Left 4 Dead 2 - though I love L4D2 as well.  KF uses iron sites, though I neither prefer nor dislike that fact, but I know some people do. If that is you, and you already love L4D2, then you will love KF as well.

As I mentioned, each class has specific skills (or perks as the game refers them) and they level with use as you meet the criteria for each. Addtionally, each class has weapon proficiences for the various types of weapons that can be found during play or purchased (with in-game money - no P2W ["pay to win"] here!) at the store prior to the start of each new level.

If you like zombies/infected, and especially like blasting them to hell, then you will have pretty much endless joy in this game - so just get it!  If you love co-op survival games, regardless of zombies, you will also love this game as its action packed each level and every map.

Additionally, there are plenty of people online at every hour of the day across many servers, so never a time where you will not be able to find a full party to play with, even after 4 years in to the release!  The Critic Metascore of 72 simply does not do this game its rightful justice.

Each level gets progressively tougher, but you can play on servers from easy to insanely difficult, so just work your way up as you get better to harder game settings/servers.  You will absolutely have fun in this game at every session, period.

Killing floor is a great title for those that enjoy slaying hordes upon hordes of zombies. It has a nice selection of weapons at your disposal, with various classes to experiment with. The community within the game are generally quite helpful, and since it's  not a competitive slag fest like other FPS titles I could name, there is a reason to work together as a team.

Not many games get this right, but Killing Floor is a fine example of something very simple, but very well executed.
MUST HAVE!!!!!

After nearly 100 hours of fun I must say Killing Floor is one of the best games ever. It has some iffy hitboxes and there are some glitches (some of which make you unable to shoot and utterly screw you), but they don't come up very often. The game also has some notably shitty voice acting, but that can be almost funny. If it's on sale (you should wait for 75% off since it happens fairly often), buy it.

Killing Floor is an outstandingly fun zombie shoot-em-up that is quick to pick up but will take countless hours to master. New events happen periodically and typically match up with the timing of Steam Sales. Thus, despite its 4.5 year old release-date, the game is still super fun to play!

This is the FPS I have put the most time into, ever. Once you pick this game up you will not be able to put it back down again for a very long time, the leveling system also makes sure of this. This game has been out for a very long time now and many expansions have been added and the game has been changed in various ways. I think this game may have become confusing for a beginner now due to the overhwelming amount of newly implemented things to understand which were directed at players who had run out of things to do. New players may find they have no time to learn things properly because it sticks you straight in the deep end with only seconds to read about what is even going on before you are being smashed over the head left right and center by some of the scariest looking monsters you have seen (unless you want to play alone of course, which you dont)
Best co-op Zambie game. Ever. EVER DAMNIT.

As FPS games go, there's nothing revolutionary about Killing Floor's gameplay. However, this game is -fun-.

The default game mode, the titular "Killing Floor", pits up to six players against progressively stronger waves of zombi- sorry, "Specimens", some of which possessed of special abilities, like the Siren's disorientating scream (making them more like Banshees) or the Bloat's corrosive bile. Between waves, a Trader appears in one of several locations where you can purchase weapons and ammunition.

One of the more interesting features of this game is its progression system; when you enter a match you choose a "Perk", a sort-of character class, that confers damage bonuses and price discounts with a particular weapon type (among other bonuses), along with corresponding criteria for ranking up (e.g. the Field Medic ranks up by healing other players). However, the beauty of the system is that you do not need to be using a perk to rank it up. All players come equipped with a medical syringe that they can use to heal themselves and their teammates with. All players can purchase any weapon, although there is a limit to how many they can carry. You can rank up any perk you like, simply based on what you choose to bring to bear against the Zo- Specimens.

There's nothing especially impressive about the game's graphics, although I should stress that there's also nothing -wrong- with them. They convey this dark, grim horror atmosphere, which is accentuated by the Zom- Specimens themselves, often grotesque and genuinely frightening creatures, who have a habit of sneaking up on you. However, this is somewhat contradicted by the voice-acting. The female Trader NPC uses vaguely suggestive and flirtatious dialogue, but appears to have no idea exactly what she's saying. The player characters are almost all Cockney-accented wideboys, with the in-game voice commands conveying a desire for money for weapons as "anyone spot me a tenner?", or gratitude as "nice one, Cyril."

The strength of the game's sound and graphical assets would definitely be its weapons. The guns look and feel great, with a successful headshot popping a Zomb- SPECIMEN'S head like an over-ripe tomato. Each perk has at least one associated weapon type, including pistols, shotguns, rifles, assault rifles, SMGs, RAWKET LAWNCHAIRS and a nice variety of melee weapons. Several are available only as DLC, but for the most part these are just re-skins of standard weapons, and do not impact the game's progression.

I like this game. Despite the somewhat repetitive nature of the Killing Floor mode, it's the sort of game I can play for hours at a time, especially if I'm playing with friends. The game has its own push-to-talk voice chat, as well as text and the aforementioned voice commands. There is an "Objective Mode" I have not yet tried, so I cannot comment on how it plays. If I had a minor complaint, it would be the seemingly large leap in difficulty between "Beginner" and "Normal", and I would highly recommend new players wait until they have achieved Rank 3 in a favoured Perk before attempting anything beyond the first setting. 

Regardless, I highly-recommend it, especially for a Steam Sale price.

TL;DR VERSION:

Pros:
- Neat Perk system
- Nice variety of weapons
- Weapons look and sound great
- Fairly easy to pick up and play

Cons:
- Gameplay may become repetitve for some people
- Poor voice acting clashes with the graphical tone of the game
- Large difficulty spike between settings.

All-in-all, this is a really good game for me, and I heartily recommend it to anyone who likes shooting zombies.
